DefineScope.Description: The first sentence should define the scope of the article, following the recommended UniProt naming conventions.

Examples.Compliant: ALDOA is a protein that in humans is encoded by the ALDOA gene.
Examples.NonCompliant: ALDOA is an important protein involved in many processes.

UseUniProtName.Description: Use the recommended UniProt protein name if it is relatively short, otherwise use the HUGO gene symbol with disambiguation if necessary.

Examples.Compliant: ALDOA is a protein...
Examples.NonCompliant: Aldo-keto reductase family 1 member A is a protein...

SummaryConciseness.Description: The lead must summarize the article concisely, covering key aspects like structure, function, and clinical significance without unnecessary detail.

Examples.Compliant: ALDOA is a protein that in humans is encoded by the ALDOA gene. It plays a critical role in glycolysis and is involved in various cellular processes.
Examples.NonCompliant: This article discusses ALDOA, which is a protein encoded by the ALDOA gene. Various studies have shown its importance in glycolysis...

AvoidRedundancy.Description: Avoid repeating information that is already present in the infobox unless it is particularly notable or requires emphasis.

Examples.Compliant: ALDOA plays a critical role in glycolysis and various cellular processes.
Examples.NonCompliant: ALDOA is a protein that in humans is encoded by the ALDOA gene. (Repeated from infobox)

GeneInformation.Description: Include specific information about the gene, such as its location on the human chromosome, its regulation, and any known splice variants.

Examples.Compliant: The ALDOA gene is located on chromosome 16 and is regulated by various transcription factors.
Examples.NonCompliant: ALDOA is a gene involved in metabolism.

AvoidRedundancy.Description: Do not unnecessarily repeat information already contained in the infobox unless it is especially notable.

Examples.Compliant: The ALDOA gene is located on chromosome 16.
Examples.NonCompliant: The ALDOA gene is located on chromosome 16. (Repeated from infobox)

ProteinDetails.Description: Include specific information about the protein, such as splice variants, post-translational modifications, and any known structural features.

Examples.Compliant: ALDOA has two splice variants and undergoes phosphorylation at serine residues.
Examples.NonCompliant: ALDOA is involved in glycolysis and is important for metabolism.

NeutralTone.Description: Maintain a neutral tone without promoting studies, researchers, or institutions.

Examples.Compliant: Studies have shown that ALDOA plays a role in glycolysis.
Examples.NonCompliant: Dr. Smith's groundbreaking research proves ALDOA is the key to metabolism.

SpeciesExpression.Description: Describe the species in which the gene is expressed, including specific mentions if it has a wide distribution.

Examples.Compliant: ALDOA is expressed in mammals, bacteria, and fungi.
Examples.NonCompliant: ALDOA is found in many organisms.

TissueExpression.Description: Describe the tissues where the protein is expressed, specifying primary and secondary locations if applicable.

Examples.Compliant: ALDOA is primarily expressed in liver and muscle tissues.
Examples.NonCompliant: ALDOA is found in various tissues.

SubcellularLocalization.Description: Describe the subcellular compartments or organelles where the protein is located, specifying exact locations where possible.

Examples.Compliant: ALDOA is localized in the cytoplasm and nucleus.
Examples.NonCompliant: ALDOA is found in the cell.

FunctionDescription.Description: Describe the function of the transcribed protein, detailing its role in specific biochemical pathways or cellular processes.

Examples.Compliant: ALDOA catalyzes the reversible aldolase reaction in glycolysis.
Examples.NonCompliant: ALDOA is important for energy production.

ProteinInteractions.Description: List proteins that the subject protein interacts with, specifying the nature of these interactions if known.

Examples.Compliant: ALDOA interacts with GAPDH and PGK1.
Examples.NonCompliant: ALDOA interacts with other proteins.

DiseaseAssociations.Description: List diseases or conditions resulting from mutations in the gene or imbalances in protein levels, providing specific details where possible.

Examples.Compliant: Mutations in ALDOA can lead to glycolytic enzyme deficiencies, resulting in muscle weakness and hemolytic anemia.
Examples.NonCompliant: ALDOA is linked to various diseases.

NotableContributions.Description: Mention key discoveries and the contributors who made them without referencing their institutions or promoting them.

Examples.Compliant: ALDOA was first cloned by Dr. Jane Doe in 1995, identifying its role in glycolysis.
Examples.NonCompliant: Research from Harvard University discovered the function of ALDOA.

IncludeAppropriateInfobox.Description: Include one or more appropriate infoboxes based on gene/protein attributes, ensuring relevance and accuracy.

Examples.Compliant: Includes {{Infobox GNF protein}} and {{Infobox enzyme}} for ALDOA.
Examples.NonCompliant: Does not include any infobox.

InfoboxTypeAccuracy.Description: Use the correct infobox type (e.g., {{Infobox GNF protein}}, {{Infobox Enzyme}}) based on gene/protein attributes and available data.

Examples.Compliant: Uses {{Infobox enzyme}} for an enzyme with EC number.
Examples.NonCompliant: Uses {{Infobox protein}} for a non-enzymatic protein.

LimitInfoboxQuantity.Description: Avoid excessive infoboxes; place less useful ones in a section at the end if necessary to maintain article readability.

Examples.Compliant: Includes only relevant infoboxes at the top; extra infoboxes are placed in an end section.
Examples.NonCompliant: Includes numerous infoboxes cluttering the top of the article.

InlineCitations.Description: Use inline citations with <ref> tags or parenthetical citations to reference specific statements.

Examples.Compliant: ALDOA is involved in glycolysis.<ref>Reference</ref>
Examples.NonCompliant: ALDOA is involved in glycolysis. References: Reference.

ReliableSources.Description: All statements must have reliable sources, preferably peer-reviewed journals or reputable databases.

Examples.Compliant: ALDOA plays a role in glycolysis.<ref>Reliable Source</ref>
Examples.NonCompliant: ALDOA plays a role in glycolysis.

ConsistentCitationFormat.Description: Citation format must be consistent within the article, either using manual formatting or citation templates uniformly.

Examples.Compliant: All citations use {{Cite journal}} templates.
Examples.NonCompliant: Mix of manual citations and templates.

AvoidGeneralReferences.Description: Do not use non-specific or general references without linking them to specific statements to ensure verifiability.

Examples.Compliant: Each statement has its own reference.
Examples.NonCompliant: Multiple statements refer to a general reference at the end.

HyperlinksInCitations.Description: Supply hyperlinks for PubMed abstracts, DOIs, and freely available full texts where applicable to enhance accessibility.

Examples.Compliant: {{Cite journal | doi=10.1002/... | url=http://...}}
Examples.NonCompliant: {{Cite journal | title=...}}

NoRetrievedDatesForConvenienceLinks.Description: Do not add 'Retrieved on' dates for convenience links to online paper journals; they are unnecessary and clutter citations.

Examples.Compliant: {{Cite journal | url=...}}
Examples.NonCompliant: {{Cite journal | url=... | retrieved=2024-01-01}}

UseCitationTemplates.Description: Prefer using citation templates like {{Cite journal}}, {{Cite book}}, etc., to ensure uniformity and ease of formatting.

Examples.Compliant: {{Cite journal | author=Smith J | title=Study on ALDOA | journal=Bioinformatics | year=2020 | doi=10.1002/...}}
Examples.NonCompliant: Smith J (2020). Study on ALDOA. Bioinformatics.

IncludeRelevantNavboxes.Description: Include one or more navigation boxes relevant to related proteins or categories to facilitate navigation between related articles.

Examples.Compliant: Includes {{Cytoskeletal Proteins}} and {{Ion channels}} navboxes.
Examples.NonCompliant: Does not include any navigation boxes.

AtLeastOneCategory.Description: Add the article to at least one relevant category to ensure it is discoverable within Wikipedia's category system.

Examples.Compliant: [[:Category:Proteins]]
Examples.NonCompliant: No categories added.

AppropriateSubcategories.Description: Use categories or subcategories appropriate to gene and protein articles, avoiding overly broad or unrelated categories.

Examples.Compliant: [[:Category:Enzymes by function]]
Examples.NonCompliant: [[:Category:Biology]]

UseSpecificCategories.Description: Whenever possible, use more specific categories to enhance article specificity and discoverability.

Examples.Compliant: [[:Category:Glycolysis enzymes]]
Examples.NonCompliant: [[:Category:Metabolic processes]]

LinkToCorrectWikidataItem.Description: Link the article to the Wikidata item corresponding to the first entity mentioned in the lead section, ensuring it reflects the correct scope (e.g., protein vs. gene).

Examples.Compliant: Links to steroid 21-hydroxylase protein Wikidata item.
Examples.NonCompliant: Links to the gene Wikidata item instead.
